Thanks!  The Log4j folks put out two new versions (2.17.0 and 2.17.1) to address more vulnerabilities that have been discovered, so my last two commits were upgrading 2.16.0 -> 2.17.0 and then 2.17.0 -> 2.17.1.

Definitely worth running things (e.g. the controller) standalone to make sure logs are still coming out like you expect them to.

@aholowko Thanks for the PR. The commit looks good to me. Let's get it merged once the CI pipeline finishes.

@narendly it took a while but here's PR that aims to solve the issue by daemonizing `GC_THREAD`: https://github.com/apache/helix/pull/1936

Also a small correction to reproduction steps: simply referencing `ZkBucketDataAccessor` is not enough to trigger the issue. `ThreadPoolExecutor` threads are not prestarted by default so it is necessary to schedule some task on `GC_THREAD` to create the thread and trigger the issue.
Thanks @hmhagberg for making the change. Approved and will be checked in when CI finishes running.
Approved by @junkaixue , I will merge the PR shorty.
Since this PR seems to be created by an automated bot, I'm not sure if it's able to use the template. Given the simple and clear nature of the change, we'll go ahead and get this merged in.
This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/1731391075
Could you please provide more information, like a code snapshot, to clarify the problem?
Is this related to either https://github.com/apache/helix/issues/1938 or https://github.com/apache/helix/issues/1802?
@narendly Not a duplicate issue, but in general related, sure. It's specifically about a single StaleMessage being logged for every resource on the instance.

@qqu0127 Looks good to me except the issue @zhangmeng916 raised. Please also check the boxes in the PR description before final checkin (btw, I think the first paragraph you have should be merged into the Description section).

@qqu0127 I would like a clarification please: the final choice of assignment logic is one of the three choices, is that correct? If so, the benchmarking should be done in offline code and only the best one should be selected and checked in. Let me know if I have a misunderstanding.

> @qqu0127 I would like a clarification please: the final choice of assignment logic is one of the three choices, is that correct? If so, the benchmarking should be done in offline code and only the best one should be selected and checked in. Let me know if I have a misunderstanding.

@NealSun96 
Eventually, yes, I expect only one is used for non-test. I open this and include all choices in order to share the code and as a reference to help better understand the design. 
We have two options here, one is to merge this PR as it is with all 3, and cleanup in a following PR. This is targeting a project branch after all. 
Second option is to update this PR after review with a new commit. I prefer the first one though.

Ready to merge, approved by @NealSun96 
Final commit message:

Fix apache#1946 Refactor and move ClusterTopologyConfig
Move ClusterTopologyConfig from nested to a standalone class in helix/model and to be used by virtual topology group logic.

This PR is ready to be merged, approved by @NealSun96 
Final commit message:

Avoid printing redundant log messages for unrelated partitions and resources.

This PR is ready to be merged, approved by @NealSun96 
Final commit message:

Properly populate the error log messages for partitions and resource names whose replica status is in ERROR state.

This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/1775617740
@desaikomal could you please give us some examples of what can fail without this change?

> 

Essentially, you are looking at the cache to check if instance is present. If a new instance has been added but cache hasn't been updated, we will see those log messages being dropped too.

In this phase while logging messages, cache is considered source-of-truth but it can be out-of-sync wrt real cluster state.
Cleanup the unused code, this is ready for review. Thanks.

This is my first review, so please correct me if i am wrong.
1. Since this is a new feature, can we update the description with link to feature document
2. Can you fill out API/backward compatibility related sections too?
Approved by @rabashizade , I'm merging the PR.

> don't we have naming convention wrt Interface and implementation Java Classes?
I think I'm following the convention, what name specifically are you suggesting?

> 
> I agree that currently you have enum with one value and so in future, you will have more, then you will extend same interface differently?? re-using methods will not be possible with existing code.
If we are following the enum approach, then each impl is a enum value with different method implementation. I don't see any blocker for code reusing even across impls, despite minor refactor. @desaikomal

This PR is ready to merge, approved by @zhangmeng916 

Final commit message:

Introduce VirtualTopologyGroup and its assignment logic
We introduce VirtualTopologyGroup as a virtualization layer on top of physical fault zone, this commit includes its core component and assignment logic.

@r0goyal Are you using default assignment algorithm? If yes, then that's an known issue we found as flipflop assignment. Suggest you to use CRUSHED based assignment. Or if you are in 1.0+, you can try WAGED.
Thanks @rahulrane50.  Change looks good to me based on version change.
Please fix typo in the commit title
This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/1953973545
This test fails in: https://github.com/apache/helix/actions/runs/1954558789
code changes looks ok, but question - do we need to add any unit-tests to verify that we are passing those options appropriately to ZK?

> code changes looks ok, but question - do we need to add any unit-tests to verify that we are passing those options appropriately to ZK?

Thank you for the review. My reasoning for not adding unit tests was that there is currently no logic in Helix itself that uses these modes, and simply testing just the getMode() return values doesn't add much value. Moreover, testing the getMode() return values seems to be more of a Zookeeper test rather than a Helix test. But please let me know if these don't sound reasonable, I am open to adding tests.
